title: Doppler - bicycle and air both move at v0

content.question: Student <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is riding a bicycle at a constant velocity <math alttext="vector v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mover><mi>v</mi><mo>â†’</mo></mover><mn>0</mn></msub></math> to the right, as shown in the figure, and the surrounding air is moving at the same velocity. The bicycle has a horn that emits sound with a rest frequency of <math alttext="f sub R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>R</mi></msub></math>. If the bicycle is approaching Student <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, who is at rest, how does the sound frequency heard by Student <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> compare to <math alttext="f sub R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>R</mi></msub></math>? What evidence or reasoning supports the claim?

choices.label: It is equal to <math alttext="f sub R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>R</mi></msub></math>. The observer is stationary.
It is equal to <math alttext="f sub R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>R</mi></msub></math>. The sound source is stationary relative to the air, the sound medium.
It is higher than <math alttext="f sub R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>R</mi></msub></math>. Air, the sound medium, is approaching the observer.
It is higher than <math alttext="f sub R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>R</mi></msub></math>. The sound source is approaching the observer.

content.answer: It is higher than <math alttext="f sub R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>R</mi></msub></math>. The sound source is approaching the observer.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
